metadata.Title: CVE-2018-16883 on Ubuntu 14.04 ESM (trusty) - low.
metadata.Description:
sssd versions from 1.13.0 to before 2.0.0 did not properly restrict access to the infopipe according to the "allowed_uids" configuration parameter. If sensitive information were stored in the user directory, this could be inadvertently disclosed to local attackers.

Update Instructions:

Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2018-16883` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
by updating your system to the following package versions:

libipa-hbac0 - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
libnss-sss - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
libpam-sss - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
libsss-idmap0 - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
libsss-nss-idmap0 - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
libsss-sudo - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
python-libipa-hbac - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
python-libsss-nss-idmap - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
python-sss - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
sssd - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
sssd-ad - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
sssd-ad-common - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
sssd-common - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
sssd-dbus - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
sssd-ipa - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
sssd-krb5 - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
sssd-krb5-common - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
sssd-ldap - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
sssd-proxy - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
sssd-tools - 1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7
No subscription required

notes.Note: mdeslaur> fixed in 2.0.0 during code refactor as of 2021-08-18, no minimal fixes available

criterions.comment: sssd package in trusty, is related to the CVE in some way and has been fixed (note: '1.11.8-0ubuntu0.7').
